title: R-Ladies Miami: R + Tableau: Let’s Enrich Data Science with More Visualizations
description:
Hong Wang, data scientist at Independent Purchasing Cooperative, which is a supply chain management company and provides supply chain service for Subway (US top 2 quick service restaurant brand). The general business is to assure that all Subway restaurants both in US and Canada operate successfully with high quality products and most competitive cost. As a data scientist at IPC, Hong provides in-depth analytical insights and systematic applications, which are both important to improve business. She applies mathematical approaches to solve business questions and enable business stakeholders to make decisions based on my analysis or recommendations.

At IPC, Tableau is used as a reporting application that is able to connect directly to R. The functionality is designed for the domain expert who understands the data and is able to make data science results more visual to broaden audience. The drag-and-drop interface allows users effortlessly connect to libraries and packages, import saved models or write new ones directly into calculations and visualize them in seconds.

description:
# Schedule
Tuesday, March 17th, 6:30-8:30pm
6:30 - [Networking Activity] R-Ladies Networking Scavenger Hunt
6:55 - Announcements
7:00 - [Career Corner] Advancing Your Career in 2020 & R Adoption in the Enterprise

8:30 - Meeting Adjourned

# Meeting Location
UC Irvine Campus
School of Medicine
Building and Room TBA
Here are a few helpful maps of UCI to help you find us: https://www.parking.uci.edu/maps/map_services.cfm

# Parking
- All vehicles parked on the UC Irvine campus are required to display a valid parking permit at all times. Permit dispensers are available in all parking structures/lots at all times and accept major credit cards (Visa, MasterCard, American Express, Discover) and cash. If you don't already have a parking permit, parking is $2/hr. The closest parking lots to the event are lots 82, 83, and 84.
- Here are a few helpful maps of UCI to help you find where to park: https://www.parking.uci.edu/maps/map_services.cfm

# Food & Freebies
- Healthy vegan and gluten-free snacks and water will be provided.
- Free R-Ladies and tidyverse stickers will also be given out.

# Presentations
[Career Corner] Advancing Your Career in 2020 & R Adoption in the Enterprise
Speaker: Louis Columbus

[R Time] A Sports Statistics Show and Tell
Speaker: Jason Wilson, PhD
Abstract:
The contents of this presentation will be drawn from the qopbaseball.com project which began in 2010, two years after I completed my Ph.D in Statistics. It originated with a clever student's IntroStat class final project! The research consists of 1 patent-pending statistical model for calculating the quality of a baseball pitch, 8 million Major League Baseball (MLB) pitches calculated, 12 thousand lines of R code, 15 MLB teams consulted, and 1 active Twitter handle @qopbaseball. In the first part of the presentation (~30min.), I will tell the origin story and development, with special attention given to the R work and lessons learned along the way. The second part of the presentation (~20min.) will be guided according to audience interest. I will take questions on any aspects of the project. I will have code and data on hand for demonstration. Sample data will be provided for audience explorations.

# Live-streaming & Meeting Materials
- All announcements and presentations will be live-streamed and recorded starting at 7:00 PM. Join us at this link: https://youtu.be/2S1CO3v1g58
- All materials will be sent out and posted on our GitHub (https://github.com/rladies-irvine) after the event.

# Technology Support & WiFi
- Extension cords and outlet strips will be provided to power your devices (i.e. smartphones, tablets, laptops). Please note that bringing a device is not required to attend our meetings. **Note:** If you would like to work with the provided sports data during the meeting, please bring your laptop with R installed and a charging cable.
- Free UCI Guest WiFi will also be provided. Please use ExpressReg to register your device and connect: https://oit.uci.edu/reg
More information about connecting to UCI Guest WiFi can be found here: https://www.oit.uci.edu/mobile/registration/

title: trigeR - Trójmiejska Grupa Entuzjastów R: Deep Learning in R - part II – Stochastic Gradient Descent and Backpropagation
description:
With the release of the R Keras package (https://keras.rstudio.com/) (by JJ Allaire and Francois Chollet) at the end of 2017 / beginning 2018 the topic of artificial neural networks and especially deep learning in R became red-hot within the R community.

„Deep Learning in R” will be a series of workshops during which you will learn how to use Keras/Tensorflow to solve different deep learning problems using Feedforward, Convolutional, and Recurrent Neural Networks. During workshops we will go through problems like image classification, object localization/detection, image segmentation, dimensionality reduction, time series forecasting, various NLP tasks and more. We will also talk about interpretability of Machine/Deep Learning models using LIME and DALEX packages.

In our second workshop we will talk about Stochastic Gradient Descent, Backpropagation and implement MLP .

After workshop we will have some pizza and drinks :)

Requirements:

Knowledge from first meeting: https://www.meetup.com/Trojmiejska-Grupa-Entuzjastow-R/events/267136487/

During workshops unfortunately there will be no internet connection so participants have to download scripts and datasets before meeting: https://github.com/maju116/trigeR_deep_learning_with_keras_in_R

title: R-Ladies Freiburg: Tidy Tuesday - Come and practice your R skills
description:
Do you want to practice your R-skills? Do you want to improve your abilities to clean, analyse and plot data?

Then this event is what you need! We will use the data from Tidy Tuesday as an excuse to work with R. We will meet to work independently using the same data-set. Each one can choose which analysis to perform or which tools to use (you can already think what you want to practice or learn). We will do this together to have the opportunity to ask others and because coding together is fun!

This activity is for everyone, from beginners to experts. You will set your own goal. We will have a coffee (or what ever you prefer) while working together. This way we can have the opportunity to ask others, to share ideas and code!!

Tidy Tuesday a weekly data project aimed at the R ecosystem. Every week a new data set is uploaded and analysed by the community, then the plots can be shared! Las week data from the fires in Australia was analysed. Have a look at some of the community plots on Tweeter:

https://twitter.com/hashtag/tidytuesday

Bring your own laptop.

title: R-Ladies Barcelona: Sanofi and Data Science: Forecasting, what and how
description:
In this talk we will explore what it’s like to be a Statistical Forecaster at Sanofi and how to apply statistical and machine learning methods to timeseries data.

19:00 - 20:30: “Sanofi and Data Science: Forecasting, what and how” workshop by Alexandra Abós
20:30 - 21:00: Pica-pica & Networking

**WARNING** The registration for this event is done through eventbrite. Please register at the following link or you will not be granted a space: https://www.eventbrite.es/e/entradas-sanofi-and-data-science-forecasting-what-and-how-88399524357

--> About Time Series Forecasting
Time Series forecasting is a hot topic in the pharma industry. However, what do we understand as time series? What are the most recent trends in the market and requirements to analyze this data? How does a top tier pharmaceutical company use time series for sales forecasting?

If you’re eager to know the answer to these questions, please join our next meet-up event!

**WARNING** The registration for this event is done through eventbrite. Please register at the following link or you will not be granted a space: https://www.eventbrite.es/e/entradas-sanofi-and-data-science-forecasting-what-and-how-88399524357

--> About Alexandra Abos
Alexandra graduated in Biomedical Engineering at UB in 2015 and has a PhD in machine learning and graph theory applied to medical imaging. She is currently working as Statistical Forecaster at the pharmaceutical company Sanofi where she focuses on time series forecasting.

--> Where?
Sanofi Offices (Meridian Building, Carrer de Rosselló i Porcel, 21, 08016 Barcelona)

--> What do you need to follow this workshop?
This is a talk, not a workshop so you don't need to bring anything more than your curiosity!

--> Attending the Meetup
Remember that in the R-Ladies Meetups we expect to have a majority of R-Ladies, so if you are a man you should come with another R-Lady or invite a non-male friend to the Meetup!

title: R-Ladies Baltimore: R-Ladies Baltimore -- Shiny apps!
description:
R-Ladies Baltimore (Bmore) is the local Baltimore chapter for the larger R-Ladies global organization (rladies.org) to promote gender diversity in the R community.

We will have an event on Wednesday January 29, 2020 from 5:30-7pm at Allovue (https://allovue.com). Amanda Plunkett (https://twitter.com/DrAmandaRP) will present on what are Shiny apps, how you can you can build them, and demo-ing a few ones we love! Come learn how to make interactive web apps with R shiny! This will be a hands-on presentation, so bring your laptop.

Also, come prepared with:
- RStudio installed
- R shiny package installed: In the RStudio console run install.packages("shiny")

WHO is this for?
- If you are new to R & are short-budgeted on time!
- If you heard of this thing called 'Shiny' in R, but no idea what it is!
- If you know about Shiny apps, but no idea how to build one!
- If you just want to see some awesome examples of web applications in R!

*If any/all of this is true, this event might be for you!*

title: R-Ladies Manchester: R-Ladies Manchester Fun with Functions!
description:
R-Ladies first event of 2020

The wonderful Autotrader have agreed to have us back for our first event of 2020 and Kaylea is going to be teaching us all how to "do" functions after giving several impromptu lessons at previous meet-ups!

There will be an "intro to functions" talk to ease you in, with a short hands on session to try it out.

Then we'll kick things up a notch and do some more advanced function uses; think the apply family, pipes and map, again breaking off into groups to try it out.

Then finally we'll open the floor up to your questions and make sure everybody leaves with at least one function that works!

This slightly more intermediate level lesson is still perfect for you if you are new to coding - the sooner you start using functions the sooner you can master them - don't be intimidated - bring your laptop along and we'll help you hit the ground running!

title: R-Ladies Lancaster: R Markdown and tips from the RStudio Conference
description:
For our first meeting of 2020 we have two talks lined up:

Rebecca Killick (Lancaster University): R Markdown and why I love it (workshop)

R Markdown is a fantastic tool allowing users to write a huge variety of documents with R code embedded. Rebecca will introduce R Markdown and explain why she loves using it. She'll also teach us how to create a simple R Markdown document. If you want to to participate in the interactive element, please bring a laptop with RStudio and R installed. If you have chance also install the knitr package by running the following command.

install.packages("knitr")

---

Rhian Davies (Jumping Rivers) : What I learnt at RStudio Conference

I'm lucky to be attending the RStudio Conference this year. I'll give a talk summarising some of the new and exciting things I learnt at the conference to share with you all!

---
We will be in Lancaster University Library - Room C135. The session will run from 6pm - 8pm with a short break in the middle. Snacks and soft drinks will be provided.

---

R-Ladies Lancaster is part of a global initiative, R-Ladies Global, designed to improve the gender diversity of R users worldwide and in particular, to improve the participation and experience of women in the R community. As part of the initiative, R-Ladies Lancaster will host a number of talks and workshops about the use of R. It doesn't matter if you never used R or if you are an R expert, R-Ladies Lancaster welcomes anyone with an interest in R.

Questions? E-mail: [masked]

title: MünsteR (R Users Group): Time Series Anomaly Detection: Tech and Biz Considerations
Düsseldorf R User Group: Live stream of rstudio::conf(2020), feat. speakers from RStudio and Google Brain
description:
Hi everyone! We'll start the year off, sponsored by trivago (https://www.trivago.com/), by participating in a world-wide live streaming of rstudio::conf(2020):

*** Agenda ***
• 16.40 - 16.55: Early arrivers are welcome to grab a drink and seat
• 16.55 - 17.00: Quick introduction
• 17.00 - 18.00: Pre-event (interviews, Q&A)
• 18.00 - 19.00: RStudio introduction and keynote (Hadley Wickham, J.J. Allaire)
• 19.00 - 20.00: Google Brain keynote (Fernanda Viégas, Martin Wattenberg)
• 20.00 - Open ended: Socialise

Because of the time difference, we'll start a little early, but you're welcome to join after the event starts of course :) Please remember to bring your ID card - our security company requires it to provide you a guest badge!

-----------------------------------------

*** Open Source Software for Data Science ***

Open-source software is fundamentally necessary to ensure that the tools of data science are broadly accessible, and to provide a reliable and trustworthy foundation for reproducible research. This talk will delve into why open source software is so important and discuss the role of corporations as stewards of open source software. I'll also talk about how RStudio is structured and organized to pursue its mission of creating open source software for data science.

J.J. Allaire is a software engineer and entrepreneur who has created a wide variety of products including ColdFusion, Open Live Writer, Lose It!, and RStudio.

-----------------------------------------

*** Data, visualization, and designing with AI ***

Recent progress in machine learning has raised a series of urgent questions: How can we train and debug deep learning models? How can we understand what is going on inside a neural network? And, perhaps most important, how can we design systems that serve people best? We'll show a series of examples from the People+AI Research (PAIR) initiative at Google--ranging from data visualizations for researchers, to tools for medical practitioners, to guidelines for designers--that illustrate how thinking carefully about data can lead to better tools, more effective design, and help humans and AI work together.

Fernanda Viégas and Martin Wattenberg are pioneers in data visualization and analytics. Their research has helped shape the field, and the systems they've built are used daily by millions of people. Fernanda and Martin are co-leaders of Google's PAIR (People + AI Research) initiative, which focuses on making AI technology broadly accessible and reflective of human values. Their prior work at Google has appeared on the Google search page, on YouTube, and in mission-critical internal data analytics tools.

Before joining Google, at IBM Research, the two created the ground-breaking public visualization platform Many Eyes, which introduced visualization to millions of users worldwide. Viégas and Wattenberg are also known for visualization-based artwork, which has been exhibited in venues such as the Museum of Modern Art in New York, London Institute of Contemporary Arts and the Whitney Museum of American Art.

-----------------------------------------

Thanks to trivago for hosting & sponsoring this edition of the Düsseldorf R User Group Meetup. There will be food and drinks available.

title: R-Ladies Washington D.C.: Survey analysis: beyond the subscripts
description:
Abstract:
Analysing complex sampling -- cluster samples, unequal probabilities, stratification -- used to be a separate and somewhat isolated area of statistics. Some books on the topic might have given the impression it was mostly about the care and feeding of subscripts. In fact, well-conducted complex sampling gives data with important differences from other data sources, but ones whose impact on the analysis is limited. Modern survey analysis software is aimed at reducing the differences to a minimum, so analysts and domain experts can analyse complex surveys correctly in most straightforward cases. I will talk about how you can use the R survey package to do most of the analyses you already do, but with data from complex surveys. ​

Bio:
Thomas Lumley is originally from Australia, but worked in Seattle, at the University of Washington, for 12 years. He is currently Professor of Biostatistics at the University of Auckland, where he teaches statistics and data science. Thomas is the developer of the R survey package, and a member of R Core. He has taught workshops on R in 13 time zones.

title: Dublin R: Why R?  @ Career Zoo Limerick
description:
Why R? Limerick will be taking place in conjunction with Career Zoo Limerick, as well as some other great tech community events

Career Zoo Limerick is taking place at Thomond Park Conference Centre on Saturday 1st February.

Why R? pre-meetings are R meetups that support local R communities. The main goal is to promote the work of the Why R? foundation, who run an annual community conference in Poland.

Another purpose of those meetings is to provide space for the professional networking and knowledge exchange for practitioners and students from the areas of statistical machine learning, programming, optimization and data science.

Why R? have already managed to co-organize 30 R meetups around Central-Eastern Europe, among others in Warsaw, Prague, Amsterdam, Copenhagen or Wroclaw. Such meetings are a great opportunity to understand the needs and areas of interest of R users around the Europe.

Those meetings would not happen without the help of local R hosts who have invested a lot of time and energy in this project!

To find out more or to submit a talk, please complete the webform at the bottom of the event page. The deadline for submissions is mid-January.

title: MadR - Madison R Programming UseRs Group: Hacking Your Environment: Tips and Tricks for Efficient Workflow.
group: MadR - Madison R Programming UseRs Group
description:
Mark K will be giving a talk on making an efficient R workflow:

Start 2020 off right by developing good workflow habits. How much time do you take to set up your environment before you begin working? In this talk I'll argue that some quality attention to your set up and teardown practice goes a long way to convert your messy r-studio garage lab into a refined space station. We'll cover basics like working directory and .RProject files and more nuanced tricks like loading works in progess and preprocessed output files, setting global themes to streamline your reports' graphical styles and other things. It's time to Marie-Kondo your code.

title: Seattle useR Group (R Programming Language): Shiny in January at Ookla HQ!
description:
*** UPDATE ****
Due to snow/ice in the area, we are pushing the meetup to Wednesday, January 22nd! We hope to see you there!
****

Shiny is a great tool for R programmers and has a lot of functionality. This evening we have a fantastic treat to learn more about how Shiny has been used for industry.

First we will have some speakers from Ookla talking about they use shiny for fact-finding missions.

Next we have talks from Heather Nolis and Jacqueline Nolis. Heather Nolis is a Machine Learning Engineer at T-Mobile. Jacqueline Nolis is the Principal Data Scientist at Nolis, LLC. Jacqueline and Heather will discuss how they use, customize, and deploy shiny applications!

Date:[masked]
(No Longer -[masked]-- due to snow)

Location: Ookla HQ, downtown Seattle

Doors open: 5:30pm for social time

The first presentation will start at 6:00PM. After the presentations there will be more social time!

David Hall and Katie Jolly:
Shiny is an R package that makes it easy to build interactive applications straight from R. The Ookla Data Science team hosts frequently used fact-finding tools and RMarkdown reports in a custom-built Shiny deployment. In the first half of the meetup, Ookla's Data Science team will discuss some of the challenges with building a limited feature version of Rstudio Connect then provide a functionality demo.

Heather Nolis (Machine Learning Engineer at T-Mobile) and
Jacqueline Nolis (Principal Data Scientist at Nolis, LLC):
Making machine learning models is a core part of a data scientist’s job, but that work will only be well-received by executives if they can understand the models. The AI @ T-Mobile team has been lucky enough to get funding and people for our projects by convincing vice presidents to trust our work using fun, interactive Shiny demos with T-Mobile style and branding. In this talk we’ll cover our process of creating Shiny demos, the tools we use to make them look T-Mobile magenta, and the technology we use to quickly deploy them (spoiler, it involves Docker). We’ll also show off a few of the interactive demos we made with some audience participation.

We look forward to seeing you at this sure to be fantastic meetup!

Please email/message Ellis Hughes if you have ideas for future Meetups you would like to see or organize.

title: Seattle useR Group (R Programming Language): Relational data models with the dm package
description:
At this meetup we have a great presentation from Kirill Müller of cynkra. Fresh off of RStudio::Conf, lets keep the R enthusiasm going!

Kirill will present {dm}, a new package that facilitates working with multiple tables. Three principal use cases can be identified: consuming a data model, building in-memory or local data models without relying on relational databases, and preparing consistent relational data models for consumption by others. Based on these use cases, he outlines the features of this package and discusses future development. The presentation will be interactive with live coding and a script that attendants can run during or after the presentation. The package is available on GitHub at https://krlmlr.github.io/dm.

Kirill works on the boundary between data and computer science with more than 20 years of software engineering experience. He enjoys working with and contributing to the R ecosystem since 2012. In 2018 he joined forces with Christoph Sax to found cynkra, a Zurich-based consultancy that helps businesses and government institutions better understand their valuable data and communicate the insights, with a focus on the R ecosystem. https://cynkra.com

If you are wanting to have your own meetup to discuss the cool ways you are using R, reach out to Ellis Hughes via Meetup.com!

title: Seattle useR Group (R Programming Language): WashPo Opioid Dataset - large data viz with R
description:
At this meetup we have an interesting presentation and training from Winston Saunders on data that is too large to fit into memory! We look forward to having you!

Abstract:
In 2019 the Washington Post successfully pursued a FOIA request for records of opiod shipments from the DEA's Automated Reporting System (ARCOS) spanning the height of the prescription opiod epidemic from 2006 to 2012. These data were subsequently published for 179 Million drug transactions ranging from mg to kilograms in size. While R's powerful analytical and visualization capabilities are, in principle, great for understanding the structure of the distribution network that enabled the epidemic, given the 78GB size of the dataset, efficient analysis required developing techniques, including data parsing and preparation of "summary" data sets, to dig deeply and thoroughly into the data. I'll share some of the techniques used to wrangle the raw data into more digestible summaries as well as the tools developed and the summaries themselves. We'll also explore how these summary data sets, coupled with mapping (ggmap), network analysis (network, igraph), and Shiny, can be used to reveal the magnitude the opiod epidemic and the network architecture, from manufacturer, to distributor, to consumer, that enabled it. To wrap up, we'll access one of the summary datasets and walk through a quick network visualization or mapping hands-on exercise. [To do the ggmaps mapping exercise you'll need your own API key from google]

Biography:
Winston is a data hackster with a day job. Though he first learned R in the Johns Hopkins Coursera pre-tidyverse he now enthusiastically embraces %>% and, nine times in ten, chooses slice(1:10) over [1:10, ]. He’s explored ML, NLP, AI, image processing, web & twitter bots, kaggle competitions, and lots of other applications in R. He selected his current project out of a balanced sense of responsibility and mischief.

If you are wanting to have your own meetup to discuss the cool ways you are using R, reach out to Ellis Hughes via Meetup.com!

title: Canberra R Users Group: AlphaZetta Global Analytics Summit - Sydney 2020
description:
Registration is required on the AlphaZetta site - links below.

The AlphaZetta Global Analytics Summit is a unique conference experience, built around experts sharing their knowledge, use cases, best practice and having time for meaningful interactions. It is not vendor driven - there’s no booths or selling and no big crowds - we expect only ~150 attendees. The summit provides insightful presentations, fantastic networking and discussion time at great value!

We are delighted that the next GAS will be held in Sydney on Friday 21st February at the Manly Pacific Hotel. Further details including the agenda can be found here ( https://alphazetta.ai/event/global-analytics-summit-sydney-2020/ ).

The day starts with presentations on the current state of the analytics market and key trends to look for in the future. The second section is about inspiring attendees with keynotes from Volt Bank on creating a new business based on data and analytics and from Raiffeisen Bank on building an analytics team to provide true value to the whole organisation.

The afternoon focuses on innovation and implementation. We have presentations from some of Australia’s exciting startups (Volt, Adgile Media, Self Assured Pty Ltd) who are using analytics to disrupt their markets. To close, we will hear a keynote on how to deliver analytics and increase AI adoption.

The Summit venue is the Novotel Pacific, Manly which is right on the ocean beach, with lunch and dinner included.

All up, at just $240 for early bird or $360 for standard tickets, it’s a conference like no other!

Presenters Include:

Steve Weston - Co-Founder and CEO, Volt Bank

Dr. Zeringue is a Statistician/Data Scientist at Mercy Hospital.

Space provided by Microsoft (thanks Amy!) and food provided by Net Effects (thanks Stephanie!).

Hope to see you there!

title: R-Ladies St. Louis: Qualitative analysis in R
description:

Mary Painter is a doctoral candidate in political science at the University of Missouri St. Louis.

Hope to see you there!

title: R-Ladies St. Louis: Making personal websites with blogdown
description:
Join us in welcoming Dr. Dorris Scott, who will lead a workshop on how to make your own professional or personal website using the blogdown package in R.

Dr. Scott is new to St. Louis and will be working as a social science data guru at Washington University in St. Louis.

Check out Dr. Scott's website: https://dscott.netlify.com/

Space for the Meetup provided by Microsoft (thanks Amy!) and food provided by Net Effects (thanks Stephanie!).

title: R-Ladies Berlin: rstudio::conf(2020) Watch Party
description:
Rstudio::conf(2020) watch party in cooperation with RStudio, RLadiesBerlin, BerlinR, and the Berlin RUG!

Let us enjoy the conference without having to trek to San Francisco. We'll watch and discuss live streams together, enjoy RStudio trinkets and have food and drinks as well.

Schedule
***********************************
5 pm - Just before the first keynote, a live-streamed pre-game event will feature short interviews with folks from RStudio as well as the wider R-Community. During this event, we will have an opportunity to interact with the host and guests in real time.

6pm - The pre-game event will lead directly into the keynote and session live-streams. We aim to watch the first two keynote talks of the conference together and we can pose questions to the speakers.

Keynotes:
- Open Source Software for Data Science, J.J. Allaire - Hosts, Founder and CEO RStudio
- Data, visualization, and designing with AI, Fernanda Viegas and Martin Wattenberg, Google

About rstudio::conf:
***********************************
Featuring two days of content with more than 70 sessions and lightning talks, rstudio::conf will welcome more than 2000 attendees to listen, discuss, and explore what’s possible with R and RStudio.

Link to Agenda: https://tinyurl.com/yyvyx66c

********************************************************************************
stay tuned for more details!

title: Taiwan R User Group / MLDM Monday: MLDM Monday | 用 ggplot2 畫選舉圖表
group: Taiwan R User Group / MLDM Monday
description:
[Topic]
用 ggplot2 畫選舉圖表

[Abstract]
這次想跟大家分享如何用 R 當中的 ggplot2 套件畫出選舉圖表/草圖，這些圖表可以直接使用，也可以另外輸出 SVG ，在其他軟體中後製。
實際使用的資料有兩部分，第一部份是 2020 台灣總統與立委選舉資料，第二部分是台大 2015~2017 的學代選舉與出席率資料。
因為著重選舉圖表，所以地圖部分會包含一般的地圖、蜂巢圖(hexmap)、示意地圖(cartogram)、議會席次圖；非地圖部分包含常見的散點圖、堆疊長條圖等。

[Agenda]
- 地圖 - 2020選舉
- 非地圖 - 台大學代選舉與出席
- QA

[對象]
- 適合對 R 語言有一定基礎的人
- 適合使用過 ggplot2 套件、想知道更多樣圖表製作的人
- 不適合想產出設計師等級超精美圖表的人
- 不適合想聽選情分析的人

[Speaker]
Dennis Tseng，台大工商管理學系在學生，目前在 Yahoo Taiwan 擔任實習分析師，對統計、商業分析、資料分析、資料新聞、資訊視覺化都很有興趣，超級喜歡 R！

title: R-Ladies Denver: R-Ladies Meetup
description:
Hello Denver Rladies!

The theme of the December meeting is R use case presentations (part 2) in addition to Gina presenting some of her materials for the upcoming January R conference. For those sharing during this event please plan on sharing a couple of slides about your own R use case, whether it is for personal or academic/professional projects. We will plan on everyone presenting their slides, saving some time for questions at the end of each presentation. I'm thinking each presentation would last 5-10 minutes (depending on how many attendees we have).

Feel free to reach out with any questions and pass along this announcement to more “RLadies”.

Meghan

title: R-Ladies Boston: January Event: Data Gets Personal
description:
In this talk, Louisa Smith will describe her experience collecting and analyzing some very personal data: data relating to her breast cancer treatment. From digging deep into her health insurance website to tracking her drug-induced hot flashes, Louisa will detail how she ended up with the data in this powerful twitter thread: https://twitter.com/louisahsmith/status/1179429494664388609. Whether you are interested in learning more about collecting data about yourself or just want to know how R can serve both as a tool to cope during stressful times and as a tool for advocacy, join us!

Louisa is currently a PhD candidate in epidemiology at Harvard TH Chan School of Public Health. She has been using R for five years in both her professional and personal lives. You can find her at https://www.louisahsmith.com and on twitter @louisahsmith.

Pizza will be served (thanks to BMS!) and the presentation will begin at 6:15

title: R-Ladies Austin: ALL the Ladies in Tech Happy Hour: Winter Edition!
description:
***NOTE: RSVP is on Eventbrite for this event! Here's the link: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/all-the-ladies-in-tech-happy-hour-winter-edition-tickets-84699168493***

This is a quarterly mega happy hour / networking mixer with the goal of connecting women in tech, data, and code in ATX. We're thrilled that we'll have Adelbert's Brewery all to ourselves again -- thanks to the folks there for opening especially for this happy hour!

We'll be partnering with Dress for Success Austin to do a drive for shoes and purses at this event -- if you have any extra shoes, purses, toiletries, or cosmetics, please bring them to help women who are in need! They also have created a handy Amazon wishlist of items they are in need of. Please consider donating if you are able.

This event is cohosted by these groups:

+ R-Ladies Austin
+ Women in Data Science
+ PyLadies ATX
+ Women Who Code
+ ChickTech Austin
+ Austin Women in Technology
+ AnitaB.org Austin
+ Lesbians Who Tech
+ Austin Women Tech-Ops
+ Society of Women Engineers Austin
+ Black Tech Women
+ Queer Up Tech

Please reach out if you know of a group that would like to co-host with us!

Feel free to bring guests, but please note that we are limiting this event to those who identify as women or minority genders only.

Can't wait to see you all there!

title: R-Ladies Calgary: R-Ladies Calgary inaugural meetup
description:
Welcome to R-Ladies Calgary!

This is our first meeting and we would love to meet as many of you as possible! Come along and meet fellow R enthusiasts, have some snacks, and help us decide the direction for the Calgary Chapter.

For those of you who aren't sure what R-Ladies is about, it is a worldwide organisation that aims to achieve proportionate representation of minority genders in the R community (including but not limited to cis/trans women, trans men, non-binary, genderqueer, agender).

Please fill out the following questionnaire before attending: https://forms.gle/g9w6BZQ83V28BQ8a8

We are looking forward to meeting you!

title: GURU::mvd: Watch party: RStudio::conf 2020
description:
Si no podés ir a la rstudio::conf(2020), ¡te la traemos a Montevideo!

Durante este evento, los asistentes a las watch parties tendrán la oportunidad de interactuar con los oradores y los invitados en tiempo real.

Al final podremos ver el streaming de uno de los 4 tracks de charlas.

¡Le agradecemos a la Facultad de Ingeniería de la Universidad de la República por el espacio, y a RStudio por la oportunidad, la comida y las sorpresas!

title: Newcastle Upon Tyne Data Science Meetup: Data Science North East: January Meeting
group: Newcastle Upon Tyne Data Science Meetup
description:
Details
Schedule:

6:00 - Food and drinks
6:30 - Matthew Forshaw (NCL Uni): Best practice in reproducible data science in R
7:15 - Matt Edwards: An Introduction to Interpreting Machine Learning Models

An Introduction to Interpreting Machine Learning Models

Abstract: The most accurate predictive models in Machine Learning are often the least interpretable (e.g. random forest) and the most interpretable models are often the least accurate (e.g. linear regression). Hence, there is often a conflict between accuracy and interpretability. We want the most accurate models but don’t want to sacrifice interpretability. In this talk, I discuss this conflict and some new methods in Machine Learning for interpreting ANY predictive model so you do not have to sacrifice predictive accuracy. A package (https://github.com/mt-edwards/xrayspecs) is also introduced that provides these new methods for R programmers.

title: Meetup de Grupo de Usuarios de R de Málaga: 11ª reunión de Grupo de Usuarios de R de Málaga
group: Meetup de Grupo de Usuarios de R de Málaga
description:
Hola, comenzamos el año 2020 con un Taller. Para próximos talleres iremos insertando formación de algunos paquetes R.

Jueves 30 de enero a las 19:00. La duración será de una hora y media aproximadamente.

Título: Random Forests con aplicación a investigación biomédica
Autor: Gabriel Aguilera

Enlace de cartel (difundir la charla, reenviando este correo y/o el enlace):

https://drive.google.com/file/d/1JYTDnGqbRQXGc7Ii822eMuIOCHTGhych/view?usp=sharing

"Los árboles de decisión y la técnica denominada Random Forest están entre los métodos más interesantes, eficientes y usados en ciencia de datos.

Se utilizan en problemas de regresión, clasificación, etc.
(ver https://bookdown.org/content/2031/ensambladores-random-forest-parte-i.html)

Gabriel es profesor del Departamento de Matemática Aplicada, conocedor de muchos lenguajes de análisis y programación, nos va a contar su experiencia con R y cómo se usa actualmente en un centro de investigación biomédico.

Vamos a trabajar en el taller con un problema real de diagnosis médica con datos reales que vamos a tener la suerte de poder usar. El taller pretende enseñar a usar las técnicas de árboles de decisión y de random forest. "

Lugar: Laboratorio[masked] (sitio habitual de anteriores charlas).

Recomendación - traer vuestro portátil los que podáis y tengáis acceso a la wifi de la UMA. Seguimos renovando laboratorio (en 2020 esperamos que ya toque), para los que no tengáis acceso a la wifi de la UMA, usaremos los ordenadores que tenemos. Dar las gracias al Departamento de Matemática Aplicada por su colaboración.

Límite de asistentes: 50 plazas

Como siempre, luego una/s cerveza/s y/o refresco/s.

Com siempre, si conocéis a alguien que se apuntó antes en el grupo de usuarios pero no está en Meetup, por favor, indicarle que a partir de ahora trabajamos para coordinarnos usando Meetup.

Manda esta información a interesados en nuestro grupo. Enlace de cartel del grupo de R:

https://drive.google.com/file/d/1YjmB79A7rASn6ib0YsJH8D6qXnR_XFvc/view?usp=sharing

(difundir el cartel del grupo)

¡Un saludo!
